oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Front porch of Cleveland Hall
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Front porch detail of Cleveland Hall. Shows the one-story Greek Portico with four fluted Doric columns, pediment, and triglyphs on the frieze. The double doors are flanked by transom windows.

Cleveland Hall, a brick Federal-style home, was built between 1839 to 1840 by Stockley Donelson (a descendant of Colonel John Donelson and nephew of Rachel Jackson). The home was designed by Joseph Reiff and William C. Hume, who had previously built the hermitage. The Donelson family were some of the earliest settlers in middle Tennessee. Stockley, a lawyer and planter, was friends with Andrew Jackson and helped with his business affairs. Additionally, Andrew Jackson was a frequent visitor of Cleveland Hall.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jones, Lester
